items.title: DeepSeek ‘punctures’ tech spending plans, and what analysts are saying
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese AI firm, aims to challenge U.S. AI leaders with advanced models at lower costs.
- Its mobile app topped charts in key markets including the U.S., UK, and China shortly after launch in January 2025.
- Wall Street's reaction is mixed; Jefferies warns of impacts on capital expenditures in AI, while Goldman Sachs sees potential shifts in competition between tech giants and startups.

items.title: TalkTalk investigating data breach after hacker claims theft of customer data
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- TalkTalk is investigating a data breach involving stolen personal information of millions of customers.
- A hacker, using the alias ‘b0nd’, claims to have stolen data of over 18.8 million current and former subscribers, including names, email addresses, and subscriber PINs.
- TalkTalk disputes the hacker's claim, stating the number is significantly overstated, with approximately 2.4 million actual customers.
- The breach is linked to unexpected access of a third-party supplier’s system, though no financial data was compromised.
- TalkTalk previously faced a £400,000 fine for a 2015 breach where hackers accessed data of 157,000 customers, including financial details.

items.title: Perplexity submits a new bid for TikTok
items.summary:
- Perplexity AI has submitted a revised proposal to merge with TikTok, aiming to give the U.S. government up to 50% ownership of the new entity.
- The proposal includes a government stake after an IPO of at least $300 million and potential continued ownership for ByteDance.
- The bid was revised based on feedback from President Trump's administration, amidst ongoing discussions about TikTok's ownership and regulation in the U.S.

items.title: DeepSeek gets Silicon Valley talking
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Chinese AI company DeepSeek released an open version of its reasoning model R1, sparking discussions in the tech community.
- R1 matches or beats OpenAI's o1 model on certain benchmarks, with training costs reportedly only $5.6 million.
- DeepSeek's success was achieved despite U.S. sanctions on advanced chips for Chinese companies, raising concerns about its implications for American AI firms.
- Industry reactions include support from venture capitalists and skepticism from others who question the authenticity of the company's claims.
- DeepSeek's AI assistant has become the top free app in the Apple App Store, surpassing ChatGPT as of Sunday.

items.title: Why Reid Hoffman feels optimistic about our AI future
items.author: Reid Hoffman, Greg Beato
items.summary:
- Reid Hoffman’s new book *Superagency* argues that AI can enhance human agency, leading to better knowledge and improved lives.
- Hoffman emphasizes the importance of 'smart risk taking' over blind optimism regarding technology.
- He supports intelligent regulation but believes with iterative deployment, AI tools can be improved through continuous user feedback.
- Discussion includes the benefits of AI, its societal impacts, and categorizing different perspectives on AI (bloomers, gloomers, doomers).
- AI's role in society is framed as one that can provide collective advantages, exemplifying how innovation leads to safety and agency.

items.title: 2025 will likely be another brutal year of failed startups, data suggests
items.summary:
- In 2024, 966 startups shut down, a 25.6% increase from 769 in 2023.
- AngelList reported 364 startup winddowns in 2024, a 56.2% jump from 233 in 2023.
- Most shutdowns attributed to high valuations and lack of product-market fit, leading to cash shortages.
- Projections indicate continued shutdowns in early 2025, with a gradual decline expected later in the year.
- Majority (60%) of startups that fail do not have enough capital to return to investors.

items.title: As demand for data centers soars, real estate companies look to become energy developers
items.summary:
- Brendan Wallace, co-founder of Fifth Wall Ventures, discusses the shift in real estate due to rising demand for data centers and energy requirements.
- Real estate firms are exploring opportunities to become energy developers to support data centers amid challenges like high office vacancy rates and market volatility.
- The growing need for data centers relates to the explosion of AI technologies, leading to increased energy demands.
- Wallace emphasizes the necessity for renewable energy solutions, particularly solar, as companies pivot towards being energy developers.

items.title: Trump administration reportedly negotiating an Oracle takeover of TikTok
items.summary:
- The Trump administration is negotiating for Oracle to take over TikTok along with U.S. investors.
- A bill was passed last year forcing ByteDance to either sell TikTok or face a ban in the U.S.
- TikTok briefly went dark before the law took effect on January 20, 2025, until Trump announced a delay of the ban.
- Trump proposed a joint venture idea of 50% U.S. ownership.
- A deal may allow Oracle to control TikTok globally while ByteDance retains a minority share.
- Previous attempts to force a sale during Trump's first term did not materialize, but TikTok shifted U.S. traffic to Oracle servers since then.
- Some senators who backed the ban-or-sell bill are confused about Trump's current plans.

items.title: Will states lead the way on AI regulation?
items.summary:
- In 2024, California enacted 18 new AI laws, with Governor Gavin Newsom also vetoing significant AI legislation.
- Mark Weatherford believes 2025 will see increased state-level regulatory action on AI compared to federal efforts.
- Over 400 state-level AI-related legislation pieces were introduced in the last year, indicating significant activity in regulating AI.

items.title: OpenAI wants to take over your browser
items.author: Cody Corrall
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched a research preview of Operator, an AI agent that can perform tasks like booking accommodations and making reservations.
- Operator will first be available to U.S. users on ChatGPT’s $200 per month Pro subscription plan.
- Elon Musk and Sam Altman are publicly disputing the funding for the Stargate project, which targets data centers for AI workloads.
- Security vulnerabilities in Subaru's web portal allowed hackers to remotely unlock and track cars, which have now been fixed by Subaru.

items.title: Paul McCartney calls on UK government to protect artists from AI
items.summary:
- Paul McCartney urges the UK government to modify copyright laws to protect artists from AI exploitation.
- He argues that proposed changes would allow tech companies to use online content without artists' consent.
- McCartney acknowledges the benefits of AI but warns about the financial risks for artists if their work is not protected.
- Emphasizes that emerging artists should benefit economically from their creations rather than tech companies.

items.title: Wall Street banks plan sale of X debt at a discount
items.summary:
- Bankers are preparing to sell debt used to finance Elon Musk’s social network, acquired for $44 million in 2022 with $13 billion financed.
- Morgan Stanley is leading the effort to sell senior debt at discounted rates between 90 and 95 cents on the dollar.
- X has faced volatility since Musk's takeover, impacting advertiser confidence despite claims of improving financials.

items.title: Retro Biosciences, backed by Sam Altman, is raising $1 billion to extend human lifespan
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman supports Retro Biosciences, a biotech startup aiming to extend the human lifespan by 10 years.
- The company is raising a $1 billion Series A round, having previously received $180 million in seed funding from Altman.
- Retro Biosciences plans to launch drug trials targeting diseases like Alzheimer’s and has collaborated with OpenAI to convert regular cells into stem cells.
- CEO Joe Betts-LaCroix aims to discover and develop drugs within the 2020s, joining other billionaire-backed ventures in longevity research.

items.title: UnitedHealth confirms 190 million Americans affected by Change Healthcare data breach
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- UnitedHealth confirmed that a ransomware attack on Change Healthcare affected around **190 million people** in America, nearly double earlier estimates.
- The February 2024 cyberattack is noted as the largest breach of medical data in U.S. history, causing extensive outages across the healthcare system.
- Data stolen includes personal identifiers and medical information, with **ALPHV ransomware gang** responsible for the breach using stolen credentials that lacked multi-factor authentication.

items.title: Character AI Seeks Dismissal of Lawsuit, Citing First Amendment Protection
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Character AI filed a motion to dismiss a lawsuit claiming the platform is protected by the First Amendment.
- The lawsuit, filed by Megan Garcia, alleges her son's suicide was connected to his addiction to a Character AI chatbot.
- Character AI plans to roll out safety features in response to the lawsuit but opposes drastic changes that might limit chatbot interactions.
- Counsel argues that the First Amendment protects against liability for harmful speech, including AI chat interactions.
- The case highlights ongoing concerns regarding minors' interactions with AI and the lack of studied mental health effects from such technologies.

items.title: AI companies upped their federal lobbying spend in 2024 amid regulatory uncertainty
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Companies significantly increased lobbying expenditures on AI issues at the federal level in 2024, with 648 companies involved compared to 458 in 2023, a 141% increase.
- Key legislation supported includes the CREATE AI Act and the Advancement and Reliability Act.
- OpenAI's lobbying expenses rose to $1.76 million in 2024 from $260,000 in 2023, while Anthropic increased its spending from $280,000 to $720,000.
- Major legislative activity included over 90 AI-related bills considered by Congress and more than 700 proposed laws at the state level.
- High-profile developments included California protecting voice artists and the veto of significant regulation by Governor Newsom.
- The federal regulatory environment is uncertain, especially with actions taken by President Trump to curtail AI regulations.

items.title: ElevenLabs has raised a new round at $3B+ valuation led by ICONIQ Growth, sources say
items.author: Ingrid Lunden, Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- ElevenLabs raised a Series C funding of $250 million, achieving a valuation of $3 billion to $3.3 billion.
- The funding round is led by ICONIQ Growth, with previous investors like Andreessen Horowitz also mentioned.
- The startup specializes in AI-driven synthetic voice technology, including voice cloning and dubbing tools.
- Investors have shown increased interest due to significant growth in ElevenLabs' technology and its applications in various industries.
- The company was founded in 2022 by Mati Staniszewski and Piotr Dabkowski, who aimed to improve the quality of dubbing in media content.
- ElevenLabs' technology includes features for translating text to speech, voice cloning, and creating new voices, catering to companies across gaming, publishing, and technology sectors.
- Its annualized recurring revenue (ARR) is reported to have grown significantly, indicating robust demand and uptake of its services.

items.title: X expands its vertical video feed to global users
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s X is rolling out its vertical video feed globally, following its U.S. debut days earlier.
- The feature is confirmed to be available in regions such as India, Australia, and parts of Europe.
- Currently, the rollout is limited to iOS users, with no timeline provided for Android availability.
- The video feature aims to enhance user engagement and allow for ad placements, similar to strategies used by other social networks like Instagram and TikTok.
- Video content has been a significant focus for X, with previous launches including a standalone TV app and enhanced video discovery features.

items.title: TechCrunch Disrupt 2025 tickets now on sale: Lowest rates ever
items.summary:
- TechCrunch Disrupt 2025 tickets are now on sale at the lowest rates of the year.
- The event will be held from October 27 to 29 at Moscone West in San Francisco.
- 250+ sessions, 200+ discussions, and Startup Battlefield 200 are featured.
- Early bird rates can save attendees up to $1,100; deadlines are on January 31 and February 28, 2025.
- Attendees can enjoy special tracks on AI and space alongside networking opportunities.

items.title: Waymo lobbyist activity in SF skyrocketed in 2024
items.summary:
- Waymo lobbyists met with San Francisco officials 348 times in 2024, more than double the 137 times in 2023.
- The increase in activity corresponds with Waymo's expansion plans in San Francisco and the Bay Area.
- Waymo aims to operate its robotaxi service at San Francisco Airport and has expanded its coverage area significantly since last year.

items.title: Ditching Meta? Open source alternatives to Instagram, TikTok, and WhatsApp fundraise on Kickstarter
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- The developer of open source apps Pixelfed, Loops, and Sup is fundraising on [Kickstarter](https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/pixelfed/pixelfed-foundation-2024-real-ethical-social-networks?ref=discovery_category&total_hits=55428&category_id=342).  
- These apps are part of the growing fediverse, utilizing the ActivityPub protocol.  
- The Kickstarter campaign has raised $58,383 with a goal of $1 million to support development and hiring.  
- Pixelfed has launched its mobile app, while Loops is currently in alpha testing, and Sup is said to be coming soon.  
- The campaign also aims to establish the Pixelfed Foundation as a non-profit and will fund the development of a blogging app.  
- There are over 200,000 users on Pixelfed.social, making it the second-largest server in the fediverse, underlying the need for expanded resources and features.

items.title: Open source alternatives to Instagram, TikTok, and WhatsApp raise funds on Kickstarter
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Developer Daniel Supernault is raising funds on [Kickstarter](https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/pixelfed/pixelfed-foundation-2024-real-ethical-social-networks?ref=discovery_category&total_hits=55428&category_id=342) for open source apps: Pixelfed, Loops, and Sup.
- The trio aims to offer alternatives to Instagram, TikTok, and WhatsApp, contributing to the fediverse using the ActivityPub protocol.
- The Kickstarter campaign has raised $58,383, surpassing its original goal.
- Supernault's long-term vision includes making these apps available to a billion users.
- The apps are intended to ensure user control and privacy against centralized social media.
- A fourth project, [Pubkit](https://pubkit.net/), will provide tools for fediverse developers.
- Funds will support expanding user management and developing an alternative blogging app.

items.title: Stargate will use solar and batteries to power $100B AI venture
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- The $100 billion Stargate joint venture will be partially powered by solar and batteries.
- Solar power installations will be built by SoftBank-backed SB Energy, but will not be the only energy source.
- Stargate is a partnership between OpenAI, Oracle, and SoftBank to create new data centers for AI applications.
- The U.S. Department of Energy predicts data centers could consume up to 12% of U.S. power by 2028.
- Nuclear power is being considered by many tech firms, but faces delays; solar and wind farms can be built faster.
- Stargate may prioritize solar power to meet urgent energy demands for data centers.

items.title: iOS 18 hits 68% adoption across iPhones, per new Apple figures
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Apple reports that iOS 18 has reached 68% adoption across compatible devices since its release in September 2024.
- In devices released in the last four years, the adoption rate is higher at 78%.
- 19% of all iPhones are still using iOS 17, with 13% on earlier versions.
- iPadOS 18 shows lower adoption at 53%, with 63% for recent models.
- Key feature of iOS 18 is Apple Intelligence, introduced with version 18.1, which has encountered some issues requiring adjustments.

items.title: Neko Health’s unicorn-sized Series B is larger than some Series C rounds
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- Neko Health raised $260 million in Series B funding at a $1.8 billion valuation.
- The funding round is notably larger than some Series C rounds.
- Co-founded by Spotify's Daniel Ek, Neko Health specializes in body scanning technology.

items.title: The EU wants to talk to US tech companies ahead of Germany’s upcoming election
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- The EU will conduct a 'stress test' on tech companies regarding misinformation ahead of Germany’s snap federal election in February 2025.
- Tech companies invited include X, Meta, Snap, TikTok, Google, Microsoft, and LinkedIn, to meet on January 31.
- The meeting will address compliance with the EU’s Digital Services Act and how firms would respond to potential disinformation scenarios affecting the election.

items.title: The AI industry’s pace has researchers stressed
items.summary:
- AI researchers experience high stress due to intense competition and rapid advancements in the industry.
- OpenAI and Google have been launching numerous new tools, increasing pressure on researchers.
- Researchers report long working hours and a lack of work-life balance as common in the AI field.
- The focus on commercialization and competition has diminished academic collaboration among researchers.
- Graduate students feel overwhelmed by the fast-paced nature of AI research and a prevalent ‘publish or perish’ mentality.

items.title: People are benchmarking AI by having it make balls bounce in rotating shapes
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- The AI community is testing how AI models handle programming tasks with a benchmark involving a bouncing ball in a rotating shape.
- DeepSeek's R1 model outperformed OpenAI's o1 pro mode according to user reports on X.
- The benchmark highlights the challenges of creating effective AI measurements, as results can vary widely based on prompts used.

items.title: US users dumped RedNote after Trump paused the TikTok ban
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Following the pause of the TikTok ban by Trump, U.S. users rapidly abandoned the app RedNote.
- RedNote had gained significant traction, reaching 32.5 million daily active users on the day before the ban but saw a 54% decline in users after the ban was put on hold.
- Users had initially flocked to RedNote to express their dissatisfaction with lawmakers and to avoid returning to Instagram's Reels.
- The cultural exchange on RedNote between U.S. and Chinese users included discussions on societal issues, but the temporary popularity of the app is unlikely to last as TikTok continues to operate in the U.S.

items.title: French e-bike startup Angell nears bankruptcy
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Angell, a French smart electric bike startup, is declaring insolvency and seeking judicial liquidation.
- Co-founder and CEO Marc Simoncini confirmed the closure, citing a hardware defect as the cause.
- Angell was founded in 2019 and faced reliability issues with its first-generation bikes, impacting customer safety.
- The company has partnered with SEB for manufacturing, but now plans to either recall or reimburse for faulty bikes, which is financially challenging.
- Owners of Angell bikes may lose access to electric assistance and smart lock services as the company may shut down its servers.

items.title: Kodiak has made its first driverless truck deliveries to customer Atlas Energy
items.author: Rebecca Bellan
items.summary:
• Kodiak Robotics has completed its first commercial launch with two autonomous trucks delivered to Atlas Energy Solutions.  
• Atlas began driverless operations in December 2024, delivering 100 loads without a human safety driver in the Permian Basin.  
• This marks the first case where a customer owns and operates the driverless vehicles without the AV company's involvement.  
• Kodiak aims to sell its AI Driver-as-a-Solution, focusing on technology rather than running its own shipping operations.  
• The Atlas deal is part of Kodiak’s near-term go-to-market strategy amidst ongoing pilots for highway operations.  
• Kodiak is generating revenue from Atlas through a combined hardware and software subscription model, including modular sensors and self-driving software.  
• An office has been established in Odessa, Texas, for operational support, with plans to expand the Kodiak team.

items.title: Threads is testing ads in the U.S. and Japan
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Meta's Threads is launching ad tests with select brands in the U.S. and Japan.
- Instagram head Adam Mosseri emphasized that feedback will be crucial before expanding the ads to more markets.
- Early ad formats will be image ads marked with a "Sponsored" label, and users will have controls for ad topics.
- Threads, which started in 2023, has grown to over 275 million monthly active users as of now.

items.title: Sam Altman’s World now wants to link AI agents to your digital identity
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- OpenAI CEO Sam Altman announced the launch of Operator, an AI agent that acts autonomously on the web.
- Altman's World project aims to create tools linking AI agents to people's online personas for verification.
- World project utilizes blockchain technology for digital 'proof of human' tools, derived from a biometric identity scan.
- Tools for Humanity, leading the project, has faced controversies, including temporary bans in some countries.
- World ID technology could license AI agents to act on behalf of users.
- Businesses may change permissions to allow AI agents for user interactions, enhancing sales opportunities.
- Altman's ventures create a network aimed at centralizing AI technologies, with potential integration with OpenAI.

items.title: Flip, the TikTok Shop rival, launches a creator fund that grants up to $100M of equity
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Flip is a social commerce app enabling shoppers to become creators and earn money by sharing reviews.
- The newly introduced creator fund offers up to $100 million in grants, ranging from $6,000 to $100,000 depending on engagement, with aims to distribute up to $1 million daily for the first month.
- Eligibility requires creators to have a minimum of 4,000 followers and 10 videos with at least 3,000 views in the past month, or 20,000 followers on other platforms.
- Within 72 hours of the fund's launch, nearly 10,000 influencers applied, with the highest grant awarded being $67,000.
- Flip has gained 580,000 downloads in January and is currently introducing new features to enhance user engagement as part of its strategy to compete in the social commerce market.

items.title: Mark Zuckerberg says Meta will have 1.3M GPUs for AI by year-end
items.summary:
- Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg announces a significant increase in capital expenditures to keep up with AI rivals.
- Projected capex for 2025 is between $60 billion and $80 billion, up from $35 billion to $40 billion last year.
- Meta plans to install over 1.3 million GPUs in data centers by year-end and bring one gigawatt of compute online, equivalent to the power used by 750,000 homes.

items.title: OpenAI’s Stargate project reportedly doesn’t have the money it needs
items.summary:
- Stargate is a major infrastructure project for OpenAI, aiming to build data centers in the U.S.
- The project reportedly lacks a fully developed plan and necessary funding to move forward.
- SoftBank and OpenAI initially commit over $15 billion each, while total expected funding could exceed $500 billion.
- Elon Musk has publicly criticized Stargate, claiming it lacks the financial backing it suggests, causing tensions with White House aides.

items.title: Apple admits next-gen CarPlay is late, but still in development
items.summary:
- Apple originally teased the next-generation CarPlay update in 2022.
- The update aims to integrate with the instrument cluster for displaying car data like speed and climate control.
- Apple had initially planned to roll out CarPlay in a limited number of cars in 2024, but has missed this deadline.
- The company stated that CarPlay is still in development and is working with several automakers to showcase unique designs.

items.title: Google commits to combatting fake reviews in the UK after 5-year probe
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- The U.K.’s Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has reached an agreement with Google to combat fake online reviews.
- This investigation, initiated in May 2020, concluded with Google agreeing to implement strict measures to identify and remove fake reviews.
- Google will report to the CMA over a three-year period to provide updates on their progress in combating fake content.

items.title: Allara lands $26M to expand women’s hormone telehealth
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Allara has successfully raised $26 million in Series B funding, led by Index Ventures and GV.
- The company focuses on telehealth for women with hormone conditions, notably PCOS, endometriosis, and hypothyroidism.
- Allara has teamed up with major health insurance providers to cover its services, expanding to 10 states and planning nationwide coverage with the new funding.

items.title: Foyer unlocks $6.2M to help people save up to buy homes
items.author: Dominic-Madori Davis
items.summary:
- Foyer is a platform that assists users in saving for home down payments, akin to a '401k for homeownership'.
- Recently secured $6.2 million in a seed funding round led by Alpaca VC and Hometeam Ventures, along with participation from Accion Venture Lab and Clocktower Ventures.
- Foyer aims to improve financial wellness for aspiring homebuyers through personalized savings goals, real estate connections, and rewards for home purchases.

items.title: LG Electronics takes majority stake in Bear Robotics, reportedly valuing startup at $600M
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- LG Electronics agrees to acquire an additional 30% stake in Bear Robotics, gaining a majority ownership of 51%.
- The deal values Bear Robotics at around $600 million, depending on a reported $180 million investment from LG.
- This acquisition intends to integrate Bear's AI technology with LG's commercial robot unit, enhancing robotics software capabilities.
- CEO John Ha and management team will continue operations while developing synergies with LG’s robotics division.
- LG aims to advance its home and industrial robot technologies, with projects scheduled for this year.

items.title: Apple expands its in-app purchase tools to cover creator experiences, large content catalogs and more
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Apple announced the launch of the Advanced Commerce API for in-app purchases, including subscriptions and content add-ons.
- The company will maintain its existing commission structure despite the introduction of new purchase formats.
- Three use cases for the API include apps with large libraries of one-time purchases, creator-led content, and subscription add-ons.
- The initiative comes after pressure from the EU and to improve support for developer platforms like Patreon.

items.title: Apple introduces a new API to support more in-app purchase formats
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Apple announced the Advanced Commerce API to support various in-app purchase formats including subscriptions and content add-ons.
- The new API is aimed at helping developers with large content catalogs and creator-led experiences.
- The eligibility for the program includes one-time purchases, creator-led content subscriptions, and purchasing add-ons within subscription services.
- Apple is responding to demands for creator payment processing systems, particularly in light of external pressures from the EU and other entities regarding payment systems.

items.title: US indicts five individuals in crackdown on North Korea’s illicit IT workforce
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- U.S. authorities indicted five individuals for involvement in a North Korean IT worker scheme that allowed remote employment with U.S. companies.
- Indicted individuals include two North Koreans, a Mexican national, and two U.S. nationals, with several arrests made.
- The scheme operated from April 2018 to August 2024, affecting at least 64 American organizations and generating $866,255 in revenue, primarily laundered through a Chinese bank account.

items.title: Tata acquires 60% stake in Apple-partner Pegatron’s India unit
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- Tata Electronics acquired a 60% controlling stake in Pegatron’s unit in India.
- This acquisition occurs less than a year after Tata acquired Wistron’s local business.
- Pegatron, an important Apple assembly partner, operates a production plant near Chennai, Tamil Nadu.
- Financial details of the deal were not disclosed, but Tata aims to expand its manufacturing footprint in India.
- Randhir Thakur, CEO of Tata Electronics, emphasized a focus on AI and technology-led manufacturing expansion.
- Tata began iPhone assembly in India in the previous year and is emerging as a key partner for Apple in Asia.

items.title: Madrona just announced its biggest fund ever, closing on $770M as other venture funds grow smaller
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Seattle-based Madrona Capital has raised $770 million, its largest fundraise to date.
- The new capital exceeds the $690 million closed across two funds in 2022, showcasing strong investor interest.
- Madrona's managing director, Matt McIlwain, highlighted successful portfolio exits including Lexion and Octo AI.
- The firm plans to invest in AI applications across various sectors and support early-stage startups as well as Series B and C companies.
- Madrona has evolved from a group of super angels to a multi-stage investor, with a notable geographic expansion into Silicon Valley in 2022.

items.title: Reliance plans world’s biggest AI data centre in India, report says
items.summary:
- Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance is set to build the world's largest data center in Jamnagar, India, with a capacity of 3 gigawatts to meet rising AI demand.
- The new facility will surpass Microsoft's existing largest data center in Virginia, which has a capacity of 600 megawatts.
- Projected cost of the data center ranges from $20 billion to $30 billion.
- Reliance intends to power the facility mainly with renewable energy from a nearby green energy complex.
- Nvidia chips will be used in the data center, following a partnership between Nvidia and Reliance to enhance AI infrastructure in India.

items.title: Tesla’s redesigned Model Y is coming to North America in March for $60,000
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Tesla announced the redesigned Model Y SUV will be available in the U.S., Canada, and Mexico in March, starting at nearly $60,000.
- This launch coincides with the rollout in China, marking a simultaneous global release.
- The new model features a starting price of $59,990 for the 'Launch Series', offering a 320-mile range and advanced driver-assistance technology.
- Notable design changes include a new front fascia and improved interior features like rear-passenger touchscreen and powered rear seats.
- Tesla aims to refresh its aging lineup after delivering fewer vehicles in 2024 due to market challenges.

items.title: Even some of the best AI can’t beat this new benchmark
items.summary:
- The nonprofit Center for AI Safety (CAIS) and Scale AI released a new benchmark called Humanity’s Last Exam for frontier AI systems.
- The benchmark contains thousands of crowdsourced questions covering mathematics, humanities, and natural sciences, in various formats including diagrams and images.
- A preliminary study revealed that no publicly available flagship AI system scored better than 10% on the new benchmark.
- CAIS and Scale AI plan to make the benchmark accessible to the research community for further evaluation of AI models.

items.title: JetBrains launches Junie, a new AI coding agent for its IDEs
items.author: Frederic Lardinois
items.summary:
- JetBrains launched a new AI coding agent named [Junie](https://www.jetbrains.com/junie/) for its IDEs.
- Junie is designed to handle routine development tasks and understand existing projects for feature extensions.
- It scored 53.6% on the SWEBench Verified benchmark of 500 developer tasks, which is considered promising, though lower than top competitors.
- The service is tightly integrated with JetBrains IDEs, maintains human control, and aims to improve code quality.
- Currently in an early access program, Junie is available only on Linux and Mac for IntelliJ IDEA Ultimate and PyCharm Professional, with WebStorm support coming soon.
